medium: Aqueous paste on brown paper / Distemper on brown paper
provenance:
The artist, Paris (until 1913; sold for Fr 8, 000, to Bernheim-Jeune); [Galerie Bernheim-Jeune, Paris, 1913–18; sold, for Fr 8, 000, to Hessel]; Jos Hessel, Paris (1918–about 1920). Dr. Henri Vaquez, Paris (about 1920). [Rosenberg and Stiebel, New York]. P.D. McMillan, Orono, Minn., (1951–1961; bequeathed to Mia). 

Provenance is from 2003 cat. rais. and should be reviewed before publishing.
text: Édouard Vuillard was commissioned to paint this city square in Paris, the Place Saint-Augustin, by a friend who lived nearby. This is one of several large decorative panels he made in distemper, a kind of paint made with water, chalk, pigment, and animal glue. Vuillard mastered the difficult medium, used in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries for theatrical backdrops, because he liked the matte effect of the paint when it dried.
title: Place Saint-Augustin
